channel.title: Follow me as I learn to make electronic music
channel.description:
Outdated post ->
Took a break from all my classical junk and started making trance/dubstep last night ---Note #1: none of these are actual songs yet. I'm approaching this as I would with any other art and dissecting the elements and then start to analyze construction. I'm experimenting and putting together small excerpts for practice before attempting a full song, basically sound doodles. ---Note #2: I suck with dubstep, im more familiar with trance. The friend I'm going to be partnering with will be designing the dubstep parts (I did the ones already there) but I mainly enjoy making the peaks ---Note #3: Some of these wont match up, some of the drops wont make sense but thats because id be making a trance intro and then suddenly decide ill attempt some wubs lol. I just use the project files as my sketch pad. Please tell me what parts you like more so I can head in the right direction! I really want criticism. If you compare #1 to whatever the most recent one is you'll see what I do with advice!
for the latest: https://soundcloud.com/aviru http://www.youtube.com/user/Slyisith

item.dc:creator: @LilXCj LilXCj
item.description:
@LilXCj wrote:

Really enjoyed this new one, I couldn’t really get into the one before it though.

You should try a quiet section as a build up. Sort of like drop your synth and then climax into something similar to what you did at ~2:10

@New mix, sounds pretty great and I’m at about 3 minutes in so keep it up.

item.dc:creator: @LilXCj LilXCj
item.description:
@LilXCj wrote:

I like it except for the triplets could change pitch like you do in the later half of the song, it sounds a bit repetitive so you might do better shortening those sections (if you keep them the same pitch) or alter them (going down or up)

item.source: Follow me as I learn to make electronic music

item.title: Follow me as I learn to make electronic music
item.dc:creator: @LilXCj LilXCj
item.description:
@LilXCj wrote:

I agree it sounds good, so far they’re all been tasteful and unique and I like them.

I agree that there needs to be a build up, but the release after the climax (hehe) in trance music needs to “feel” uplifting. It’s hard to explain because I’m not that much into music creation, so I can’t give clear examples or explanations about what I mean.

This is my favorite trance song and since it has various sections, I wonder if this might be a good example of what I mean.

Read full topic
item.source: Follow me as I learn to make electronic music

item.title: Follow me as I learn to make electronic music
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

I still want hard drops but I need the notes to be much more uplifting

I like trance where it peaks at some point rather than just a constantly slow beat that never climaxes

I think the chorus on #9 was one of the best ive ever done, my favorite part is 4:25+, but like I said it doesn’t have the uplifting sound I want. I’m sort of fighting myself because when I write classical epic music I want a cool notes like that but when I’m doing this I don’t lol

Read full topic
item.source: Follow me as I learn to make electronic music

item.title: Follow me as I learn to make electronic music
item.dc:creator: @LilXCj LilXCj
item.description:
@LilXCj wrote:

For some of your synths on #9, you’re using them as really short notes, so it sounds more like house than trance. Like Si Force said, it sounds aggressive. Try to for the sound you had all the way up to ~1:15. I’d like to see what you could do by trying to put softer sounds.

Read full topic
item.source: Follow me as I learn to make electronic music

item.title: Follow me as I learn to make electronic music
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

Got a new one up. I’ve been so burned out. I’m running out of melodies and I’m getting sick of my songs before I’m doing making them because I hear them looping so many times and find something wrong with them

thanks rip

Si Force:

Only listened to one or two and they seemed a bit aggressive, but I have no doubt that it’s good work. Hopefully you keep working with this!

Yea I’m trying not to make them aggressive but they end up coming out like that. Must be my sound, I always like that epic stuff. #8 was too aggressive though and I didn’t like it.

Read full topic

item.title: Follow me as I learn to make electronic music
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

[quote=“LilXCj, post:27, topic:518632”]I thoroughly enjoy your latest track, very nice job.

EDIT: you don’t need to fade your track in, just start at the volume you want the track to stay at.[/quote]
Good to hear!

c|p:

am i witnessing the second coming of dj byouma

Just wait until you hear the one im working on now

EDIT: Got a new one up there

Tried to go heavier and tried new things, I kept listening to it on cheap headphones and correcting things and nothing was working to fix the bass until I realize my kicks were just too low lol… I was checking all the bass lines and tweaking them and getting frustrated

Read full topic

item.source: Follow me as I learn to make electronic music

item.title: Follow me as I learn to make electronic music
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

LilXCj:

I’m really liking the trancy stuff you have, I hope you make a long song next (per usual trance songs are 5 minutes or longer) and experiment with transitions.

Thanks, I’m being told my “peaks” are my strongest point.

And I’m working more on my instrument layering, I’ve also noticed some don’t have quite the “full” sound I want

I’m working on a real traditional trance song right now while I practice my beats, hoping to practice transitions quite a bit

[quote=“asyo4, post:25, topic:518632”]Here’s a tip: EQ every snare to around 200 HZ, it makes a great hallow-sounding snare great for glitch/dubstep.

“Rebel against anything” is a good example of 200 HZ EQ’ing: https://soundcloud.com/mason-secreti/rebel-against-anything

edit: if u need any help come to me, been producing for about a year and a half now :p[/quote]
I recently figured out how useful EQing is and now I pretty much do it to every instrument I load. Helps so much with overall quality and separating each instrument instead of letting their frequencies mush together

EDIT: Alright got another one up there, tried alot of new stuff

Read full topic
item.source: Follow me as I learn to make electronic music

item.title: Follow me as I learn to make electronic music
item.dc:creator: @asyo4 asyo4
item.description:
@asyo4 wrote:

Here’s a tip: EQ every snare to around 200 HZ, it makes a great hallow-sounding snare great for glitch/dubstep.

“Rebel against anything” is a good example of 200 HZ EQ’ing: https://soundcloud.com/mason-secreti/rebel-against-anything

edit: if u need any help come to me, been producing for about a year and a half now

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @LilXCj LilXCj
item.description:
@LilXCj wrote:

I’m really liking the trancy stuff you have, I hope you make a long song next (per usual trance songs are 5 minutes or longer) and experiment with transitions.

Although, I feel that you don’t have enough backing instruments to support your main synth instruments. But, they’re experiments so I’ll just leave this here.
